title: Lough Easkey Walk Route

images.title: Liz McCabe / Easky Lough
images.caption: Easky Lough is fed by mountain streams entering at the lake's southeastern end. The lake drains north into the Easky River, which flows north to the Atlantic Ocean near Easky village

images.title: Oliver Dixon / North end of Easky Lough
images.caption: North end of Easky Lough, 6 km from Masshill, Sligo, Ireland. On the lonely mountain road which crosses the Ox Mountains between Dromore West and Tobercurry. Fish species in Easky Lough include brown trout, salmon and the critically endangered European eel.

images.title: Liz McCabe / Isolated farm by Easky Lough
images.caption: Isolated farm by Easky Lough

images.title: Liz McCabe / Peat bog and pool
images.caption: Peat bog and pool. The Lough is part of the Ox Mountains Bogs Special Area of Conservation.

images.title: Easky Abbey by Robin Mais, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Easky Abbey. The village name derives from the Irish language term for fish ("iasc") and "Iascaigh" literally means "abounding in fish", due to the Easky River that lies adjacent to the village itself. Easky, as a parish, was originally called "Imleach Iseal". The area is a tourist destination on account of its scenery and water sports. Easky is a designated area on Ireland's Wild Atlantic Way tourist route.

images.title: Rosslee Castle and the harbour at Easky by Oliver Dixon, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Rosslee Castle and the harbour at Easky

description: This circular loop walk takes you around the picturesque Lough Easkey in west County Sligo in the Ox Mountains. The waymarked trail runs for about 6km with lovely views across the lake to the surrounding mountains. To continue your waterside walking in the area head south to try the circular walk around the pretty Lough Talt. Further to the south west is the expansive Lough Conn. Here you can visit the atmospheric remains of the ancient Errew Abbey.
display_address: Cloonacool, Cloonacool ED, Ballymote-Tubbercurry Municipal District, County Sligo, Connacht, Éire / Ireland
